div.head: To polish a ruby balay
div.ab: Unlike others, you don't polish it with tripoli, but with marcasite powder and oil.

You have to calcine your pure gold with ☿ and then wipe your amalgam well and make the said mercury fly off. Next crush it on marble with gum water. As for silver it needs to be taken raw and corroded with aqua fortis, then take it out with a copper blade and rinse it well and next grind it with gum water.

div.head: Polishing stones
div.ab: There are three wheels for this purpose, one of tin, one of lead, and one of pure copper. On the copper wheel, only diamonds, rubies, sapphires and oriental jacinths are usually polished. The tin wheel is for softer stones such as emeralds, amethysts and others.

div.head: Pewterers' mixture [illegible]
div.ab: Because they often mix in with the fine tin half the quantity of lead, which renders the tin dull. To correct this, they mix in some latten filings to make it sonorous.

div.head: Perfect amalgam
div.ab: Take the most delicate stoneware you can find, with a cavity in the middle. Put in an eighth part of ☿ in and rub it and wear it down while adding water, urc, ☾ or ☼ until the substance becomes paste-like and even harder. Next, if you want, eat it away with good aqua fortis, if it is ☾ or ♀. Then remelt it, having taken it out as you know. The ☾ will have color, and having been melted, will leave some flecks of ☼, and the ♀ will be very fine and will have almost no chappe.
